comments.commentBody:
I hope this summit really works well for the World.
http://www.necdetyilmaz.com...
This was silly.
Awesome feature!

So glad #2 mentioned www.bigislandbliss.com in Waikoloa. I've had the pleasure of staying there three times and with each visit I fell in love with the accommodations and Hawaii all over again. Beautifully appointed, well equipped, great location, spectacular views, walking distance to Roy's (fantastic restaurant), walk or easy drive to gorgeous beaches. Owners are a pleasure to deal with and take great care of the place.

Note to self, after reading Wags @ Post 8: Must.Not.Use.so.many.!!! points.... or else they will think I am a young solver *cough*...
(i used at least of them in Post #2...eek!)

Raoul's: Deep Soho, been there since 1975, great food, great atmosphere, eclectic crowd....you want a "club?" there's one where everyone is welcome, everyone has fun, and no one gets ripped off. Food a great mix between classic and contemporary. All walks of life from society WASPs to quasi-homeless and everything in between...And the staff have as much fun as the patrons. Is anything else in nyc a comparable data point? I think not. A true gem...an insiders place open to all. And don't forget to try the lobster risotto...

Nello is simply Nello and I hope it always will be.  Without Le Goulue and Fredericks in the mid-60s of Madison anymore, I'd have preferred Nello to be left untouched and unscathed.  It's not just about the pasta, it's about the real estate too.  When I step in, I choose to basque in all of its casual Upper East Side elegance and its nonchalant flashiness and extravagance--and when I don't feel like throwing money to the wind, I simply keep walking, maybe even "settle" for a pasta at Serafina.

If McDonald's can do it for its European franchises, it should make the commitment in the U.S...Clearly the company isn't doing it for ethical reasons or cage-free would be implemented in the U.S. too. They simply want to do it in Europe to make people believe they are "trying".

www.foodfitnessfreshair.com
It's an acquired tastelessness apparantly.
Those among us who frequented the salon upstairs in recent years have seen far too much of the  bizarre food handling and storage strategies to ever dream of eating there.

What seems to my way of thinking a loooong time ago I read a review in the NY Times of Mama Leone's.....up to today that was the worst and most scathing review I think I have ever read in the Times.  Today's review may surpass the one of years gone by, but maybe my memory is just failing me.

Great puzzle! Really fun fill. Impressive symmetry. Also, nice catch Patricia (comment 4)... missed that while solving. 2D was my favorite clue.

True story: when I was reading Harry Potter and the word HORCRUX was introduced, I actually thought as I was reading: "Nice! That'll be fun to try to fit into a crossword puzzle." Hard to turn off the crossword brain, sometimes, I guess... like when Tiger's marriage troubles started, the constructor part of my brain was a little happy that the word "Elin" would soon be fair game, since now she wasn't obscure. Anyway...

Solved this one with a friend, and we only struggled with one box, the crossing of GESS_ and _ST (at 1-A and 5-D). We didn't GESSO until our second try.

Two other thoughts:

1) Seems like Jonah/Will missed an opportunity to make 59A the tie-in clue for the whole puzzle... wouldn't "EARTH" SHATTERING be an appropriate title for this puzzle?

2) We were very confused at first by 28A. We remember Mount Sinai from the bible, and even Mount Ararat, but not a Mount ASS. And, as a former teenager boy, I feel like my bar mitzvah training would had been a lot more exciting if there was a Mount Ass to talk about. Surely I would have remembered something so fun. And looking it up didn't help... a word of warning: if you google "Mount Ass," do it with safe-search on. After our collective brain-FRIEZE finally went away, we got the clue, but as clever as it is, it was much more fun while we were confused.

Enjoyed it! Thanks Jonah/Will!

Only in a town where you can't swing a dead socialite without hitting a great restaurant do you have hangers-on and attention whores spending exorbitant sums for what is universally acknowledged as awful food.

I am happy to say I'd rather slum it at the Corner Bistro and chow down on a $6.75 burger and wash it down with a "Dark." Or go to one of the hundreds of establishments where the clientele is interested in the food, not whether the can see or be seen on Page SIx.... how pathetic. How sad.

We were Impaled by El Predatore alright.

Strolling along Madison, we wanted a small bite for lunch.

Initially given a table by the sidewalk. Then, upon studying my wife and me, we were quickly escorted to a back table, where upon we were immediately descended down by at least four wait staff and two hosts.

Then came a whirlwind of presenting this and that “special,” bringing out a truffle “that’s making it’s final appearance at Nello’s this week”, presented in a very nice cake dish . . . so forth and so forth. Truly a place where the attitude was “if you had to ask the price you shouldn’t be here.” Almost never saw the same server or kitchen staff twice. There was this accountant looking guy standing, kept glancing over at us every now and then – surreal almost.

Food was 6 out of 10. Bill was almost $650 for a lunch for two [entrée was $175 or so per, my wife had a run of the mill burgundy for $30].

Oh well . . .
One of the best and the finest culinary giants I have ever worked for.Moody . But. The hands ,you feel like kissing them all your life .

No surprise. These people care nothing for but their wine & the scene. They would rhink nothing of spending the yearly per-capita income of poorer countries on being "seen".  Who would go there? Not those who care about real food nor those who are not in touch with the daily struggles for many living in the United States. What an embarressment. They should flush money down the toilet. It would probably be fun for them.

Nicola's on the UES. Wonderful Italian food and service of the red sauce variety. I am aware of the benefits of being a club member. I get great treatment and a table at a moment's notice. It s nice to dine among power brokers and feel part of the scene...just by being a regular. PB

Thanks for this article so I know never ever to go to this place.  Club or no club, making good food is not hard.  Of course, it's harder to make incredible food.  But, for owners to offer medicre food because they know people will come to the "club" is insulting.

If China wants to be accepted by the Western world and not marginalized socially, then they are going to have to do some PR. Like not eating animals that the vast majority of Western households consider members of their families.
The board's position speaks for itself.
Obama is too busy spending us into oblivion to be particularly vigilant about either of his two wars.

There’s a rotting stench coming from the Obama administration’s Afghan strategy. First the White House backs Karzai through a fraudulent election so it can launch its surge anyway. Then Karzai starts going rogue, prompting more pressure on him, which leads him to threaten that he will join the Taliban. The natural response, of course, is to “freeze out” the president that America helped elect and try to go local, even though intelligence at the local level is most lacking. Bruce Riedel, a main architect of Obama’s strategy, admits the White House “never had any illusions of Karzai” and pulled the trigger on the surge anyway. Completing the charade, Clinton and Gates finally tell the American people to get off Karzai’s back. The political conditions for a successful military campaign don’t exist and yet it’s full speed ahead. Something has gone horribly wrong - when the strategy collapses it’s time to withdraw. Foreign policy day and night at www.hadalzone.blogspot.com

President Obama's foreign policy is to attack our allies and bow before our enemies.  The goal is to make sure that when he's finished, America will have no allies.  It's called "smart diplomacy".  They chose that name specifically to impress Tom Friedman.

If we lived in an ideal world, you'd be right. In fact, in theory, you are right.

But we live in a country where the votes of 5 Justices, each one voting against his or her stated principles regarding states' rights, ended a valid recount ordered by the state's supreme court, thus throwing the election to their favored candidate. We live in a country where election shenanigans are de rigueur; in fact, the Ohio election that gave the next federal election to that same candidate, was full of irregularities. And in Oklahoma, state legislators are now proposing to raise an armed militia to fight off the federal government. And an army lieutenant colonel who is a doctor has refused to be deployed because he doesn't believe the current Commander in Chief -- who was elected by a wide margin -- is legitimate.

In other words, we don't provide a great moral example of free & fair elections or respect for legitimate election results.

If there is some way to get rid of Karzai & Al-Malaki, the citizens of their countries must do that, not NATO forces or the U.S. Hey, how about impeachment? We can show them how to do that, too! In the meantime, we're stuck with the fellas we got.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

Every Democrat who calls himself or herself a believer in peace or an anti-war believer or activist is the worst kind of hypocrite. Obama is a bigger war-monger than Bush. Obama has escalated the troop numbers larger than Bush ever did, but the pretend peace rally people don't make a squeak.

Both of those wars are as unConstitutional as they ever were. Ron Paul is the only real anti-war candidate in the country. And the hypocrisy of Democrats makes them much worse than Republicans.
